I understand that being a Republican these days is a pretty miserable experience, with a Party that has been captured by extremists, no national candidates of any stature, no coherent political program (other than opposition to Obama), unfavorable demographics threatening to doom the Party to permanent minority, regional status, etc.  It's perfectly understandable that you need to put the best face you can on an impossible situation.  You are right, however, that Clinton will beat any Republican your Party puts up against her, but you're mistaken -- there are alternatives to her within the Democratic Party.  That's the big difference bet. the two parties -- the Democrats have potential candidates for president besides Clinton.  The Republicans have whom?  Ted Cruz?  Rand Paul?  Chris Christy? Mitt Romney?  Who knows now what the future holds for our two major parties.  It will become much clearer, no doubt, during Clinton's second term, 2020-2024.

It is all too easy to condemn the owner of this magnificent champion horse of his, without placing one's self in his shoes. He was within reach of having his dream come true, one that many shared, and he's not able to shrug this off genuinely with a smile, and say: 'It wasn't meant to be; perhaps this time next year. Power to the winner of this wonderful race today, and my horse Chrome is doing just fine'.

There has been so much excitement on the part of this national annual sport's event (possibly more press coverage today on California Chrome than the President of the United States).

All this accumulated excitement and noise engenders inner-turmoil; emotional stress builds up in anticipation; hope and belief continue to increase, and all this can be traumatic for anybody when all of these great expectations, are flattened within a few minutes, causing the most prepared of us in such a situation, to snap, weep or worse.

So let's have a show of heart here for the people who worked hard at today's event and care, while understanding how crushing this can be in defeat.

Perhaps some people with a love for our champion horses of the Sport of Kings will have the grace to say to Mr. Steve Coburn and Mr Art Sherman, 'Hats off to you! It was hard work, a fine run, and one that will be remembered by many of us, especially in these times of adversity. We care.

@Jasmine: Apart from the merits of your argument, which I think are lacking, the reality is that the Kentucky Derby will always attract at or about a maximum field of 20. The Preakness will attract about half of those who ran in the Derby. But if the same horse wins both? You would be lucky to get three of the Preakness AND Derby horses to run in the Belmont. Do you just want to KILL of the most challenging of the three to win? I live right around the corner from Belmont, and the elementary school that my daughters' attended has the majority of its parking and all of its athletic fields (which are huge) that were donated to it back in the 1950s by the NY Racing Association, whose then president was President of our local school board. If you are TRULY concerned with the horses' well being, you would NEVER seek to *compel* them to run in races too frequent for their well being.
The fact of the matter is that 30, 40 or 50 years ago, horses *regularly* raced twice in two weeks. Now, the only time in a horse's career that that happens is the short stretch between the Derby and Preakness.
Fair game might be to stretch out the series: Derby stays the same-First Saturday in May. Push the Preakness back to the fourth Saturday in May, and make the Belmont the last Saturday in June, just before New York Racing heads for Saratoga for the Summer Meet. That might bring better fairness.

You win some and you lose some, what I can't stand is the excuse that other horses were rested to be spoiler. Off hand, I can't think of any other major competition that the finish time haven't improve over 40 years. Big Red held the track record for all 3 legs of the Triple Crown and those were set in 1973. None of those records are broken to this day, nobody even come close. Belmont record was 2:24, and 31 length, the next best was 2:25 (today was 2:28:52, a whopping almost 5 seconds behind the record), for winning margin, you have to get back to history book, the next best was 25 length, not even close. You can "rest" all you want, but nobody even dared to try with Big Red, I think by the time Belmont came around there were only 4 or 5 horses entered, and rightly so, Sham, finished second (had beaten Big Red before also second in the other 2 triple crown legs) and 31 length behind, the other ones were not even in the radar.
The last Triple Crown winner, Affirm, had to beat back Alydar (down to the wire on all 3 races), and Affirm was ridden by a teenager.
During the pre "race", one of the commentators quoted somebody: "To win a Triple Crown, you have to have a good horse with mediocre competition". Really?? Certainly not Affirm and Big Red.

Yes, that's right... I live in Weed, CA ! (no joke)... Maureen, I feel badly about your bummer trip with edibles in Colorado, but it brings up a VERY important point. Cannabis should be legalized and highly regulated and taxed (just like alcohol). That way it can be tested for impurities and STRENGTH. Edibles should ONLY be sold in INDIVIDUALLY WRAPPED single doses, with BIG warnings (like tobacco) about the delayed reaction effect. They should NOT be manufactured in child-friendly forms (gummy bears, etc). I first smoked pot when I was 15 (1967), but stopped when I was in my late 30's. Alcohol became my "drug of choice" for recreation, but now that I'm in my 60's, the unnecessary calories, cancer and liver disease risk, and DUI risk is steering me back to cannabis.  It's been 45 years since Woodstock nation and legalization is WAY overdue. Maureen, puff a couple bowls of MODERATE strength pot, and report back to the masses about your experience. Legal weed will lead to a healthier, kinder, and more peaceful and gentle America....
